Content:
2  blasters  @  240/sec  Mem

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i added mutex to avoid the crashes after an hour, waiting for the one hour to pass to make sure it solves the issue. but an unexpected doubling in speed happened! usually when you add a mutex, the overhead slows things down. i was careful in where i put them to minimize the slowdown, but a doubling of speed was unexpected!  what that means is that without the mutex, there were a lot of hardware/system inefficiencies due to the overlapped access to the same memory by different threads. i still have txpow active, but it could be that we can achieve 20k/sec now without it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the small nodes are at 100% CPU usage

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: bug is not fixed, so things are still unstable after an hour. this will take a while to solve and i seems better to refactor that code to get a cleaner algo, then debug it if it is still crashing

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: @jl777c what part of the data blob is changed randomly for calculating txpow ?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a nonce is added to the end of the payload

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there is also a header added, one part for routing, another for the indexing

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: [relaydepth][funcid][timestamp] [index header] [payload] [nonce]

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the [payload] is the hex or ascii that is submitted (or its encrypted form)

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: got it

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
@jl777c for the command `DEX_broadcast hex priority` 
priority is 5
size of hex is 16.1KB

will the hash have 5 zero bits after 0x777 or 5 + 4 = 9 zero bits?

Author: Mark81#4505
Content: @jl777c Still wondering how it is prevented to not spam broadcasts? What prevents to create false data to network?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: what is one mans false data is another mans valuable data

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: who is to say what is spam and what isnt

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you can create data at 0 priority and if the network has capacity, it will relay it. if not, it will drop it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if you want it to not be dropped you need to increase the priority and also the hashing cost

Author: Mark81#4505
Content: For DEX orderbooks it will be very valuable to have working messaging system and probably Atomic-API relies to that function.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: when the minimum txpow is a diff of 12, it will take 1 second per message

Author: kmdkrazy#8280
Content: ill  guess amountA and  B have  to  be an integer and what about  negative values?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: how exactly do you plan to spam the network then?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: amountA and B are floating point format. you can put in negative number, but it will be converted to unsigned (big number)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is meant to be the volume of what you are selling for what you want to buy. together it creates a price

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: at one second per packet, it would take 10,000 cores to saturate the network

Author: Mark81#4505
Content: So messages are mined without actual blocks produced

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: no blocks

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: each message has txpow that is configurable

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so if the atomicDEX client notices the network is congested, it simply uses a higher priority

Author: Mark81#4505
Content: Clever!

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: just going to priority 1 makes it now take 20,000 cores to saturate the network

Author: kmdkrazy#8280
Content: got a -1 response

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: lets make it priority of 4, that is the pain threshold of 16 seconds per message to send. but now it takes 160,000 cores to saturate
